column4: It is an issue with the installation; I have finally been able to set up partitions and such, after about a week, and everything is smooth sailing up until it actually starts copying files, at which point it reports an error involving debootstrap, and says to check the log in the debootstrap directory, the log is empty, and I am not sure what to do; reading the forum they say try burning the disk really slowly, and I've just tried burning the d
slow as my hardware allows, but it still stops at about approximately 30 percent.
I tried burning it about three times.
I already said I burnt it as slow as possible, which was 8x...
I have checked the md5sum, as a matter of fact.
Should I just burn a few more disc?
If the md5 checked out fine, you suppose it would be the burn then?
I've tried it once at 8x speed and I tried the built in verifier, it said it was ok, so I could try again.
8x is the slowest my computer allows.
are you changing the mount points manually
what did you use to setup the partition
did you set it up as an ext3 partition? if so changeit to a blank partition and let ubuntu do the format.
no change it to a blank partition let ubuntu set up the space for you.
okay now boot ubuntu it should just run to the partition section then layout the system the way you want it and carry on with the install
this should erradicate the bootstrap error.  Fingers crossed
